newsitem.title: TANZANIA: About 90,000 Rwandan refugees flee camp in Tanzania.
newsitem.headline: About 90,000 Rwandan refugees flee camp in Tanzania.

text.p: About 90,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees have fled a camp in northwestern Tanzania to avoid repatriation to Rwanda, a U.N. official said on Thursday.
Julie Johnson, spokeswoman for the U.N. World Food Programme (WFP) in Ngara, told Reuters the camp at Lumasi, which had a population of 113,000, was 80 percent empty.
"It appears the camp is virtually empty," Johnson added. "All commercial activity has stopped. The WFP (World Food Programme) warehouse at Lumasi camp was looted."
The move from Lumasi brings to about 140,000 the number of refugees who have fled all the Tanzanian camps, which originally held 542,000 refugees.
Earlier on Thursday U.N. refugee agency officials said some 35,000 refugees had abandoned camps at Kitale, Lukole and Keza and headed southeast in hope of reaching Zambia and Malawi.

About 15,000 refugees fled earlier in the week from camps in northwestern Tanzania. About 560 have crossed into Uganda. Officials blame the exodus on intimidation of the refugees by the Interahamwe, Rwandan Hutu militiamen who led the 1994 genocide in Rwanda. The Interahamwe are determined not to go home because they fear reprisals or prosecution.
